contextId.information: This phrase is used to emphasize what really happened. This could be said in a positive way. AT: "there was a great disturbance among the soldiers over what had happened to Peter" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
contextId.quote: there was no small disturbance among the soldiers over what had happened to Peter

contextId.information: This could also be stated in positive form. AT: "God has certainly left a witness" or "God has indeed testified" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
contextId.quote: he did not leave himself without witness

contextId.information: This is an understatement to emphasize that many leading women joined them. AT: "many leading women" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
contextId.quote: not a few of the leading women

contextId.information: The town clerk uses "not" to emphasize that all of the people knew this. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"For I did not keep silent and not tell you." This can be stated in positive form. AT: "For I certainly declared to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
contextId.quote: For I did not keep back from declaring to you

contextId.information: This statement is made in the negative to emphasize the positive equivalent. AT: "he should die immediately" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
